answers.q: is tricalcium phosphate the same as calcium citrate
answers.a: No—tricalcium phosphate (E341iii) and tricalcium citrate (E333iii) are different calcium salts; citrate is more soluble and mainly used as a sequestrant/stabilizer and calcium fortificant, while phosphate is often an anti-caking agent and fortificant.

answers.q: is tricalcium citrate bad for you
answers.a: No—tricalcium citrate (E333iii) is approved in the EU and generally recognized as safe in the U.S. at typical food levels; excessive calcium from any source can cause GI discomfort or contribute to kidney stones in susceptible people.

answers.q: what is tricalcium citrate used for
answers.a: It’s used as a sequestrant and stabilizer to control acidity and bind metal ions, helping preserve color and texture, and it’s also used to fortify foods and supplements with calcium.

answers.q: which is better calcium citrate vs tricalcium phosphate
answers.a: For calcium supplementation/absorption, calcium citrate is often preferred because it’s more soluble and can be taken with or without food; tricalcium phosphate is less soluble but useful in foods as an anti-caking agent and when added phosphorus is desired.

answers.q: which is easier to absorb tricalcium pjosphatw or calcium citrate?
answers.a: Calcium citrate is generally easier to absorb than tricalcium phosphate, especially on an empty stomach; phosphate salts are better absorbed when taken with meals.
